properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Showers and thunderstorms will continue to soak the region today with total rainfall amounts of 15 to 30 mm likely in many areas. A few locally higher rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are also expected due to the thunderstorms. Poor driving conditions from low visibility in downpours are expected tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-21T23:13:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-21T15:14:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1014991640.2019

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Ground temperatures will cool to near freezing over many regions of the Maritimes tonight. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A slow moving disturbance will continue to bring periods of rain to southern Manitoba today and tonight. Moderate to heavy rain developed over southwestern Manitoba early this morning but was beginning to weaken by late morning. This precipitation is expected to reintensify and gradually move to the east-northeast as an upper level disturbance approaches from North Dakota. Since Thursday night a number of areas have already seen 50 to 100 mm of rain in southern Manitoba and a further 40 to 60 mm is possible over the warning area by Sunday morning. Scattered thunderstorms in the area may also produce locally higher amounts. The precipitation is expected to exit the region and move into northwestern Ontario by Sunday morning. This rainfall warning may be extended to southeastern areas of the province if conditions warrant. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-22T07:43:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-21T15:44:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3666222681.2019

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Humberto. This is the final information statement for this storm. Weakening Post-Tropical storm Humberto will soon exit the eastern Grand Banks and into the open Atlantic. 1. Summary of basic information at 12:30 p.m. NDT. Location: Near 46.0 North 47.3 West. About 453 kilometres east-southeast of Cape Race. Maximum sustained winds: 95 kilometres per hour. Present movement: East-northeast at 50 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 982 millibars. 2. Public weather impacts and warnings summary. No significant effects were expected over land. a. Wind. No significant winds were expected. b. Rainfall. Some outer rain bands from Humberto had affected the Avalon Peninsula last night and this morning. The Avalon received generally between 10 and 30 millimetres of rain as Humberto passed to the south. c. Surge/Waves. Forecasted swells of 3 to 5 metres along the southern Newfoundland coast will continue to diminish this afternoon. Storm surge values along the southeastern Newfoundland coast of 20 to 30 centimetres were reached at St. Lawrence, Argentia, and St. John's. Some continued wave action is likely along southeastern coastlines as Humberto continues to move further east today. 3. Marine weather impacts and warnings summary. The main affects from Humberto were felt along the southeastern Atlantic marine waters. Humberto tracked into Laurentian Fan as a hurricane force post-tropical storm near 12 P.M. ADT Friday and weakened slowly as it continued on an east-northeast track over the southern Grand Banks late Friday into Saturday. A storm warning is currently still in effect for the southeastern Grand Banks until this afternoon. Significant wave heights of 7 to 10 metres were forecast to the right of Humberto's track over the offshore waters. Buoy B44139 over northern Laurentian Fan who was approximately 100 km northwest of Humberto's centre reached a peak wind gust of 47 knots and significant wave height of 5.2 metres. Forecaster(s): McArthur ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-09-22T01:59:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-21T14:31:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4206491503.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada
